\int_{z}^{\infty}R_{D}\left(x,y,t\right)\mathrm{d}t=6\!R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right), \int_{0}^{1}R_{D}\left(x,y,v^{2}z+(1-v^{2})p\right)\mathrm{d}v=R_{J}\left(x,y, z,p\right).

\int_{0}^{\infty}R_{J}\left(x,y,z,r^{2}\right)\mathrm{d}r=\tfrac{3}{2}\pi R_{F }\left(xy,xz,yz\right), \int_{0}^{\infty}R_{J}\left(tx,y,z,tp\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{6}{\sqrt{p}}R_{C }\left(p,x\right)R_{F}\left(0,y,z\right).

\int_{0}^{\pi/2}R_{F}\left({\sin^{2}}\theta{\cos^{2}}\left(x+y\right),{\sin^{2 }}\theta{\cos^{2}}\left(x-y\right),1\right)\mathrm{d}\theta=R_{F}\left(0,{\cos ^{2}}x,1\right)R_{F}\left(0,{\cos^{2}}y,1\right), \int_{0}^{\infty}R_{F}\left((ac+bd)^{2},(ad+bc)^{2},4abcd{\cosh^{2}}z\right) \mathrm{d}z=\tfrac{1}{2}R_{F}\left(0,a^{2},b^{2}\right)R_{F}\left(0,c^{2},d^{2 }\right), subject to a,b,c,d>0.
See also (LABEL:eq:EL.SI.IC).
To replace a single component of \mathbf{z} in R_{-a}\left(\mathbf{b};\mathbf{z}\right) by several different variables (as in (LABEL:eq:EL.IE.JD)), see ( , (7.9)) .

These theorems reduce integrals over a real interval (y,x) of certain integrands containing the square root of a quartic or cubic polynomial to symmetric integrals over (0,\infty) containing the square root of a cubic polynomial (compare §LABEL:sec:EL.SI.DI).

Let X_{\alpha}=\sqrt{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}x}, Y_{\alpha}=\sqrt{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}y}, subject to x>y, 1\leq\alpha\leq 5, d_{\alpha\beta}=a_{\alpha}b_{\beta}-a_{\beta}b_{\alpha}, subject to d_{\alpha\beta}\neq 0 if \alpha\neq\beta, and assume that the line segment with endpoints a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}x and a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}y lies in \mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0) for 1\leq\alpha\leq 4.

If s(t)=\prod_{\alpha=1}^{4}\sqrt{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}t} and \alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta is any permutation of the numbers 1,2,3,4 , then \int_{y}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{s(t)}=2\!R_{F}\left(U_{12}^{2},U_{13}^{2},U_{23 }^{2}\right), where U_{\alpha\beta}=(X_{\alpha}X_{\beta}Y_{\gamma}Y_{\delta}+Y_{\alpha}Y_{\beta}X_ {\gamma}X_{\delta})/(x-y), U_{\alpha\beta}=U_{\beta\alpha}=U_{\gamma\delta}=U_{\delta\gamma}, U_{\alpha\beta}^{2}-U_{\alpha\gamma}^{2}=d_{\alpha\delta}d_{\beta\gamma}.
There are only three distinct U ’s with subscripts \leq 4 , and at most one of them can be 0 because the d ’s are nonzero.

Then {U_{\alpha\beta}=\sqrt{b_{\alpha}}\sqrt{b_{\beta}}Y_{\gamma}Y_{\delta}+Y_{ \alpha}Y_{\beta}\sqrt{b_{\gamma}}\sqrt{b_{\delta}},}, U_{\alpha\beta}=X_{\alpha}X_{\beta}\sqrt{-b_{\gamma}}\sqrt{-b_{\delta}}+\sqrt{ -b_{\alpha}}\sqrt{-b_{\beta}}X_{\gamma}X_{\delta}, \int_{y}^{x}\frac{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}t}{a_{\delta}+b_{\delta}t}\frac{\mathrm {d}t}{s(t)}=\tfrac{2}{3}d_{\alpha\beta}d_{\alpha\gamma}R_{D}\left(U_{\alpha \beta}^{2},U_{\alpha\gamma}^{2},U_{\alpha\delta}^{2}\right)+\frac{2X_{\alpha}Y _{\alpha}}{X_{\delta}Y_{\delta}U_{\alpha\delta}}, subject to U_{\alpha\delta}\neq 0.

\int_{y}^{x}\frac{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}t}{a_{5}+b_{5}t}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{s(t) }=\frac{2}{3}\frac{d_{\alpha\beta}d_{\alpha\gamma}d_{\alpha\delta}}{d_{\alpha 5 }}R_{J}\left(U_{12}^{2},U_{13}^{2},U_{23}^{2},U_{\alpha 5}^{2}\right)+2\!R_{C} \left(S_{\alpha 5}^{2},Q_{\alpha 5}^{2}\right), subject to S_{\alpha 5}^{2}\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0), where U_{\alpha 5}^{2}=U_{\alpha\beta}^{2}-\frac{d_{\alpha\gamma}d_{\alpha\delta}d_{ \beta 5}}{d_{\alpha 5}}=U_{\beta\gamma}^{2}-\frac{d_{\alpha\beta}d_{\alpha \gamma}d_{\delta 5}}{d_{\alpha 5}}\neq 0, S_{\alpha 5}=\frac{1}{x-y}\left(\frac{X_{\beta}X_{\gamma}X_{\delta}}{X_{\alpha }}Y_{5}^{2}+\frac{Y_{\beta}Y_{\gamma}Y_{\delta}}{Y_{\alpha}}X_{5}^{2}\right), Q_{\alpha 5}=\frac{X_{5}Y_{5}}{X_{\alpha}Y_{\alpha}}U_{\alpha 5}\neq 0, S_{\alpha 5}^{2}-Q_{\alpha 5}^{2}=\frac{d_{\beta 5}d_{\gamma 5}d_{\delta 5}}{d _{\alpha 5}}.
The Cauchy principal value is taken when U_{\alpha 5}^{2} or Q_{\alpha 5}^{2} is real and negative.
Cubic cases of these formulas are obtained by setting one of the factors in (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.s) equal to 1.

The advantages of symmetric integrals for tables of integrals and symbolic integration are illustrated by (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.F) and its cubic case, which replace the 8+8+12=28 formulas in ( , 3.147, 3.131, 3.152) after taking x^{2} as the variable of integration in 3.152.
Moreover, the requirement that one limit of integration be a branch point of the integrand is eliminated without doubling the number of standard integrals in the result.
(LABEL:eq:EL.CI.D) subsumes all 72 formulas in ( , 3.168) , and its cubic cases similarly replace the 18+36+18=72 formulas in ( , 3.133, 3.142, and 3.141(1-18)) .

For example, 3.142(2) is included as \int_{u}^{b}\sqrt{\frac{a-t}{(b-t)(t-c)^{3}}}\mathrm{d}t=-\tfrac{2}{3}{(a-b)}{ (b-u)}^{3/2}R_{D}+\frac{2}{b-c}\sqrt{\frac{(a-u)(b-u)}{u-c}}, subject to a>b>u>c, where the arguments of the R_{D} function are, in order, (a-b)(u-c) , (b-c)(a-u) , (a-b)(b-c).

(LABEL:eq:EL.LD.03) can be written I(\mathbf{m})=\int_{y}^{x}\prod_{\alpha=1}^{h}(a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}t)^{-1/2} \prod_{j=1}^{n}(a_{j}+b_{j}t)^{m_{j}}\mathrm{d}t, where x>y , h=3 or 4, n\geq h , and m_{j} is an integer.
Define \mathbf{m}=(m_{1},\dots,m_{n})=\sum_{j=1}^{n}m_{j}\mathbf{e}_{j}, where \mathbf{e}_{j} is an n -tuple with 1 in the j th position and 0’s elsewhere.
Define also \boldsymbol{{0}}=(0,\dots,0) and retain the notation and conditions associated with (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.Xd) and (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.Xda).

The integrals in (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.F), (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.D), and (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.J) are I(\boldsymbol{{0}}) , I(\mathbf{e}_{\alpha}-\mathbf{e}_{\delta}) , and I(\mathbf{e}_{\alpha}-\mathbf{e}_{5}) , respectively.
The only cases of I(\mathbf{m}) that are integrals of the first kind are the two ( h=3 or 4) with \mathbf{m}=\boldsymbol{{0}}.
The only cases that are integrals of the third kind are those in which at least one m_{j} with j>h is a negative integer and those in which h=4 and \sum_{j=1}^{n}m_{j} is a positive integer.
All other cases are integrals of thesecond kind.
I(\mathbf{m}) can be reduced to a linear combination of basic integrals and algebraic functions.
In the cubic case ( h=3 ) the basic integrals are I(\boldsymbol{{0}});, I(-\mathbf{e}_{j}), subject to 1\leq j\leq n.

In the quartic case ( h=4 ) the basic integrals are I(\boldsymbol{{0}});, I(-\mathbf{e}_{j}), I(\mathbf{e}_{\alpha}), Basic integrals of type I(-\mathbf{e}_{j}) , 1\leq j\leq h , are not linearly independent, nor are those of type I(\mathbf{e}_{j}) , 1\leq j\leq 4.
The reduction of I(\mathbf{m}) is carried out by a relation derived from partial fractions and by use of two recurrence relations.
These are given in ( , (2.19), (3.5), (3.11)) and simplified in ( , (1.10), (1.7), (1.8)) by means of modified definitions.
Partial fractions provide a reduction to integrals in which \mathbf{m} has at most one nonzero component, and these are then reduced to basic integrals by the recurrence relations.

A special case of ( , (2.19)) is given by b_{j}I(\mathbf{e}_{l}-\mathbf{e}_{j})=d_{lj}I(-\mathbf{e}_{j})+b_{l}I( \boldsymbol{{0}}), subject to j,l=1,2,\dots,n, which shows how to express the basic integral I(-\mathbf{e}_{j}) in terms of symmetric integrals by using (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.F) and either (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.D)or (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.J).

The first choice gives a formula that includes the 18+9+18 = 45 formulas in ( , 3.133, 3.156, 3.158) , and the second choice includes the 8+8+8+12 = 36 formulas in ( , 3.151, 3.149, 3.137, 3.157) (after setting x^{2}=t in some cases).

If h=3 , then the recurrence relation ( ( , (3.5)) ) has the special case b_{\beta}b_{\gamma}I(\mathbf{e}_{\alpha})=d_{\alpha\beta}d_{\alpha\gamma}I(- \mathbf{e}_{\alpha})+2b_{\alpha}\left(\frac{s(x)}{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}x}- \frac{s(y)}{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}y}\right), where \alpha,\beta,\gamma is any permutation of the numbers 1,2,3 , and s(t)=\prod_{\alpha=1}^{3}\sqrt{a_{\alpha}+b_{\alpha}t}.

(This shows why I(\mathbf{e}_{\alpha}) is not needed as a basic integral in thecubic case.)In the quartic case this recurrence relation has an extra term in I(2\mathbf{e}_{\alpha}) , and hence I(\mathbf{e}_{\alpha}) , 1\leq\alpha\leq 4 , is a basic integral.
It can be expressed in terms of symmetric integrals by setting a_{5}=1 and b_{5}=0 in (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.J).
The other recurrence relation is b_{j}^{q}I(q\mathbf{e}_{l})=\sum_{r=0}^{q}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{q}{r}b_{l}^{ r}d_{lj}^{q-r}I(r\mathbf{e}_{j}), subject to j,l=1,2,\dots,n; see ( , (3.11)) .
An example that uses (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.PF)–(LABEL:eq:EL.CI.R2) is given in §LABEL:sec:EL.OA.
For an implementation by James FitzSimons of the method for reducing I(\mathbf{m}) to basic integrals and extensive tables of such reductions, see ( ) and ( ) .
Another method of reduction is given in ( ) .
It depends primarily on multivariate recurrence relations that replace one integral by two or more.
The first formula replaces (LABEL:eq:EL.LR.04)–(LABEL:eq:EL.LR.08).
Define Q_{j}(t)=a_{j}+b_{j}t^{2} , j=1,2 , and assume both Q ’s are positive for 0\leq y<t<x.

If both square roots in (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.1d) are 0, then the indeterminacy in the two preceding equations can be removed by using (LABEL:eq:EL.AS.RD2) to evaluate the integral as R_{G}\left(a_{1}b_{2},a_{2}b_{1},0\right) multiplied either by -2/(b_{1}b_{2}) or by -2/(a_{1}a_{2}) in the cases of (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.01a) or (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.01b), respectively.
If x=\infty , then U is found by taking the limit.
For example, \int_{y}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(t^{2}+a^{2})(t^{2}-b^{2})}}=R_{F} \left(y^{2}+a^{2},y^{2}-b^{2},y^{2}\right).
Next, for j=1,2 , define Q_{j}(t)=f_{j}+g_{j}t+h_{j}t^{2} , and assume both Q ’s are positive for y<t<x.

If each has real zeros, then (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.F) may be simpler than \int_{y}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{Q_{1}(t)Q_{2}(t)}}=4\!R_{F}\left(U,U+D_{1 2}+V,U+D_{12}-V\right), where (x-y)^{2}U=S_{1}S_{2}, S_{j}=\left(\sqrt{Q_{j}(x)}+\sqrt{Q_{j}(y)}\right)^{2}-h_{j}(x-y)^{2}, D_{jl}=2f_{j}h_{l}+2h_{j}f_{l}-g_{j}g_{l}, V=\sqrt{D_{12}^{2}-D_{11}D_{22}}.
(The variables of R_{F} are real and nonnegative unless both Q ’s have real zeros and those of Q_{1} interlace those of Q_{2}.

) If Q_{1}(t)=(a_{1}+b_{1}t)(a_{2}+b_{2}t) , where both linear factors are positive for y<t<x , and Q_{2}(t)=f_{2}+g_{2}t+h_{2}t^{2} , then (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.2d) is modified so that S_{1}=(X_{1}Y_{2}+Y_{1}X_{2})^{2}, X_{j}=\sqrt{a_{j}+b_{j}x}, Y_{j}=\sqrt{a_{j}+b_{j}y}, D_{12}=2a_{1}a_{2}h_{2}+2b_{1}b_{2}f_{2}-(a_{1}b_{2}+a_{2}b_{1})g_{2}, D_{11}=-(a_{1}b_{2}-a_{2}b_{1})^{2}=-d_{12}^{2}, with other quantities remaining as in (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.2d).
In the cubic case, in which a_{2}=1 , b_{2}=0 , (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.2df) reduces further to S_{1}=(X_{1}+Y_{1})^{2}, D_{12}=2a_{1}h_{2}-b_{1}g_{2}, D_{11}=-b_{1}^{2}.

For example, because t^{3}-a^{3}=(t-a)(t^{2}+at+a^{2}) , we find that when 0\leq a\leq y<x \int_{y}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{t^{3}-a^{3}}}=4\!R_{F}\left(U,U-3a+2\sqrt {3}a,U-3a-2\sqrt{3}a\right), where (x-y)^{2}U=(\sqrt{x-a}+\sqrt{y-a})^{2}\left((\xi+\eta)^{2}-(x-y)^{2}\right), \xi=\sqrt{x^{2}+ax+a^{2}}, \eta=\sqrt{y^{2}+ay+a^{2}}.
Lastly, define Q(t^{2})=f+gt^{2}+ht^{4} and assume Q(t^{2}) is positive and monotonic for y<t<x.
Then \int_{y}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{Q(t^{2})}}=2\!R_{F}\left(U,U-g+2\sqrt{fh} ,U-g-2\sqrt{fh}\right), where (x-y)^{2}U=\left(\sqrt{Q(x^{2})}+\sqrt{Q(y^{2})}\right)^{2}-h(x^{2}-y^{2})^{2}.

For example, if 0\leq y\leq x and a^{4}\geq 0 , then \int_{y}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{t^{4}+a^{4}}}=2\!R_{F}\left(U,U+2a^{2},U- 2a^{2}\right), where (x-y)^{2}U=\left(\sqrt{x^{4}+a^{4}}+\sqrt{y^{4}+a^{4}}\right)^{2}-(x^{2}-y^{2} )^{2}.
The arclength s of the ellipse x=a\sin\phi, y=b\cos\phi subject to 0\leq\phi\leq 2\pi, with a>b , is given by s=a\int_{0}^{\phi}\sqrt{1-k^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta.
When 0\leq\phi\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi , s/a=E\left(\phi,k\right)={R_{F}\left(c-1,c-k^{2},c\right)-\tfrac{1}{3}k^{2}R_{ D}\left(c-1,c-k^{2},c\right)}, where
Cancellation on the second right-hand side of (LABEL:eq:EL.AL.E3) can be avoided by use of (LABEL:eq:EL.OF.LE4).
The length of the ellipse is L(a,b)=4aE\left(k\right)=8aR_{G}\left(0,b^{2}/a^{2},1\right)=8\!R_{G}\left(0,a ^{2},b^{2}\right)=8abR_{G}\left(0,a^{-2},b^{-2}\right), showing the symmetry in a and b.
Approximations and inequalities for L(a,b) are given in §LABEL:sec:EL.LI.CO.
Let a^{2} and b^{2} be replaced respectively by a^{2}+\lambda and b^{2}+\lambda , where \lambda\in(-b^{2},\infty) , to produce a family of confocal ellipses.

As \lambda increases, the eccentricity k decreases and the rate of change of arclength for a fixed value of \phi is given by \frac{\partial s}{\partial(1/k)}=\sqrt{a^{2}-b^{2}}F\left(\phi,k\right)=\sqrt{ a^{2}-b^{2}}R_{F}\left(c-1,c-k^{2},c\right), subject to k^{2}=(a^{2}-b^{2})/(a^{2}+\lambda), c={\csc^{2}}\phi.
The arclength s of the hyperbola x=a\sqrt{t+1}, y=b\sqrt{t} subject to 0\leq t<\infty, is given by s=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{y^{2}/b^{2}}\sqrt{\frac{(a^{2}+b^{2})t+b^{2}}{t(t+1)}} \mathrm{d}t.

From (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.D), with a_{\delta}=1 and b_{\delta}=0 , s=\tfrac{1}{2}I(\mathbf{e}_{1})=-\tfrac{1}{3}a^{2}b^{2}R_{D}\left(r,r+b^{2}+a^ {2},r+b^{2}\right)+y\sqrt{\frac{r+b^{2}+a^{2}}{r+b^{2}}}, subject to r=b^{4}/y^{2}.
For s in terms of E\left(\phi,k\right) , F\left(\phi,k\right) , and an algebraic term, see ( , p. 3) .
See ( , Ex. 9.4-1 and (9.4-4)) for arclengths of hyperbolas and ellipses in terms of R_{-a} that differ only in the sign of b^{2}.

For 0\leq\theta\leq\tfrac{1}{4}\pi , the arclength s of Bernoulli’s lemniscate r^{2}=2a^{2}\cos\left(2\theta\right), subject to 0\leq\theta\leq 2\pi, is given by s=2a^{2}\int_{0}^{r}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{4a^{4}-t^{4}}}=\sqrt{2a^{2}}R_{F} \left(q-1,q,q+1\right), subject to q=2a^{2}/r^{2}=\sec\left(2\theta\right), or equivalently, s=aF\left(\phi,1/\sqrt{2}\right), subject to \phi=\operatorname{arcsin}\sqrt{2/(q+1)}=\operatorname{arccos}\left(\tan\theta\right).
The perimeter length P of the lemniscate is given by P=4\sqrt{2a^{2}}R_{F}\left(0,1,2\right)=\sqrt{2a^{2}}\times 5.24411\;51\ldots= 4aK\left(1/\sqrt{2}\right)=a\times 7.41629\;87\dots.
For other plane curves with arclength representable by an elliptic integral see ( , p. 190) and ( , pp. 32–33) .

R_{G}\left(x,y,z\right) and R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right) occur as the expectation values, relative to a normal probability distribution in {\mathbb{R}^{2}} or {\mathbb{R}^{3}} , of the square root or reciprocal square root of a quadratic form.

More generally, let \mathbf{A} ( =[a_{r,s}] ) and \mathbf{B} ( =[b_{r,s}] ) be real positive-definite matrices with n rows and n columns, and let \lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n} be the eigenvalues of \mathbf{A}\mathbf{B}^{-1}.

If \mathbf{x} is a column vector with elements x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n} and transpose \mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{T}} , then \mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x}=\sum_{r=1}^{n}\sum_{s=1}^{n}a_{r,s }x_{r}x_{s}, and \int_{{\mathbb{R}^{n}}}(\mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x})^{\mu}\exp \left(-\mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{B}\mathbf{x}\right)\mathrm{d}x_{1}\cdots \mathrm{d}x_{n}=\frac{\pi^{n/2}\Gamma\left(\mu+\tfrac{1}{2}n\right)}{\sqrt{ \det\mathbf{B}}\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}n\right)}R_{\mu}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}, \dots,\tfrac{1}{2};\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n}\right), subject to \mu>-\tfrac{1}{2}n.
§LABEL:sec:EL.SI.SC shows that for n=3 the incomplete cases of R_{F} and R_{G} occur when \mu=-1/2 and \mu=1/2 , respectively, while their complete cases occur when n=2.
For (LABEL:eq:EL.EV.02) and generalizations see ( ) .

The function z(p)=R_{F}\left(p-x_{1},p-x_{2},p-x_{3}\right), with x_{1},x_{2},x_{3} real constants, has differential \mathrm{d}z=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\prod_{j=1}^{3}(p-x_{j})^{-1/2}\right)\mathrm{d}p, subject to \Im p>0; 0<\operatorname{ph}\left(p-x_{j}\right)<\pi, j=1,2,3.

If x_{1}>x_{2}>x_{3}, then z(p) is a Schwartz–Christoffel mapping of the open upper-half p -plane onto the interior of the rectangle in the z -plane with vertices z(\infty)=0, z(x_{1})=R_{F}\left(0,x_{1}-x_{2},x_{1}-x_{3}\right)\quad\text{($>0$)}, z(x_{2})=z(x_{1})+z(x_{3}), z(x_{3})=R_{F}\left(x_{3}-x_{1},x_{3}-x_{2},0\right)=-iR_{F}\left(0,x_{1}-x_{3 },x_{2}-x_{3}\right).
As p proceeds along the entire real axis with the upper half-plane on the right, z describes the rectangle in the clockwise direction; hence z(x_{3}) is negative imaginary.
For further connections between elliptic integrals and conformal maps, see ( , pp. 44–85) .

The surface area of an ellipsoid with semiaxes a,b,c , and volume V=4\pi abc/3 is given by S=3VR_{G}\left(a^{-2},b^{-2},c^{-2}\right), or equivalently, \frac{S}{2\pi}=c^{2}+\frac{ab}{\sin\phi}\left(E\left(\phi,k\right){\sin^{2}} \phi+F\left(\phi,k\right){\cos^{2}}\phi\right), subject to a\geq b\geq c, where \cos\phi=\frac{c}{a}, k^{2}=\frac{a^{2}(b^{2}-c^{2})}{b^{2}(a^{2}-c^{2})}.
Application of (LABEL:eq:EL.SI.CG) transforms the last quantity in (LABEL:eq:EL.AL.E5) into a two-dimensional analog of (LABEL:eq:EL.TE.01).
For additional geometrical properties of ellipsoids (and ellipses), see ( , p. 417) .

subsection.title: Potential of a Charged Conducting Ellipsoid

para.sentence: If a conducting ellipsoid with semiaxes a,b,c bears an electric charge Q , then the equipotential surfaces in the exterior region are confocal ellipsoids: \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}+\lambda}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}+\lambda}+\frac{z^{2}}{c^{2}+ \lambda}=1, subject to \lambda\geq 0.
The potential is V(\lambda)=QR_{F}\left(a^{2}+\lambda,b^{2}+\lambda,c^{2}+\lambda\right), and the electric capacity C=Q/V(0) is given by 1/C=R_{F}\left(a^{2},b^{2},c^{2}\right).
A conducting elliptic disk is included as the case c=0.

Let a homogeneous magnetic ellipsoid with semiaxes a,b,c , volume V=4\pi abc/3 , and susceptibility \chi be placed in a previously uniform magnetic field H parallel to the principal axis with semiaxis c.

The external field and the induced magnetization together produce a uniform field inside the ellipsoid with strength H/(1+L_{c}\chi) , where L_{c} is the demagnetizing factor, given in cgs units by L_{c}=2\pi abc\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}\lambda}{\sqrt{(a^{2}+\lambda)( b^{2}+\lambda)(c^{2}+\lambda)^{3}}}=VR_{D}\left(a^{2},b^{2},c^{2}\right).
The same result holds for a homogeneous dielectric ellipsoid in an electric field.
By (LABEL:eq:EL.CF.3D),
L_{a}+L_{b}+L_{c}=4\pi, where L_{a} and L_{b} are obtained from L_{c} by permutation of a , b , and c.
Expressions in terms of Legendre’s integrals, numerical tables, andfurther references are given by ( ) .
Ellipsoidal distributions of charge or mass are used to model certain atomic nuclei and some elliptical galaxies.
Let the density of charge or mass be \rho(x,y,z)=f\left(\sqrt{(x^{2}/\alpha^{2})+(y^{2}/\beta^{2})+(z^{2}/\gamma^{2 })}\right), where \alpha,\beta,\gamma are dimensionless positive constants.
The contours of constant density are a family of similar, rather than confocal, ellipsoids.

In suitable units the self-energy of the distribution is given by U=\frac{1}{2}\int_{{\mathbb{R}^{6}}}\frac{\rho(x,y,z)\rho(x^{\prime},y^{\prime },z^{\prime})\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\mathrm{d}z\mathrm{d}x^{\prime}\mathrm{d}y^ {\prime}\mathrm{d}z^{\prime}}{\sqrt{(x-x^{\prime})^{2}+(y-y^{\prime})^{2}+(z-z ^{\prime})^{2}}}.

Subject to mild conditions on f this becomes U=\tfrac{1}{2}(\alpha\beta\gamma)^{2}R_{F}\left(\alpha^{2},\beta^{2},\gamma^{2 }\right)\int_{0}^{\infty}(g(r))^{2}\mathrm{d}r, where g(r)=4\pi\int_{r}^{\infty}f(t)t\mathrm{d}t.

The mutual inductance M of two coaxial circles of radius a and b with centers at a distance h apart is given in cgs units by \frac{{c^{2}}M}{2\pi}=ab\int_{0}^{2\pi}(h^{2}+a^{2}+b^{2}-2ab\cos\theta)^{-1/2 }\cos\theta\mathrm{d}\theta=2ab\int_{-1}^{1}\frac{t\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1+t)(1- t)(a_{3}-2abt)}}=2abI(\mathbf{e}_{5}), where c is the speed of light, and in (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.IM), a_{3}=h^{2}+a^{2}+b^{2}, a_{5}=0, b_{5}=1.

The method of §LABEL:sec:EL.CI.RB uses (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.R2), (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.RR), and (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.PF) to produce 2abI(\mathbf{e}_{5})=a_{3}I(\boldsymbol{{0}})-I(\mathbf{e}_{3})=a_{3}I( \boldsymbol{{0}})-r_{+}^{2}r_{-}^{2}I(-\mathbf{e}_{3})=2ab(I(\boldsymbol{{0}}) -r_{-}^{2}I(\mathbf{e}_{1}-\mathbf{e}_{3})), where a_{1}+b_{1}t=1+t and r_{\pm}^{2}=a_{3}\pm 2ab=h^{2}+(a\pm b)^{2} is the square of the maximum (upper signs) or minimum (lower signs) distance between the circles.

Application of (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.F) and (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.D) with \alpha=1 , a_{\beta}+b_{\beta}t=1-t , \delta=3 , and a_{\gamma}+b_{\gamma}t=1 yields \frac{3{c^{2}}}{8\pi ab}M=3\!R_{F}\left(0,r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2}\right)-2r_{-}^{2 }R_{D}\left(0,r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2}\right), or, by (LABEL:eq:EL.CF.CG), \frac{{c^{2}}}{2\pi}M=(r_{+}^{2}+r_{-}^{2})R_{F}\left(0,r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2} \right)-4\!R_{G}\left(0,r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2}\right).
A simpler form of the result is M=(2/{c^{2}})(\pi a^{2})(\pi b^{2})R_{-\frac{3}{2}}\left(\tfrac{3}{2},\tfrac{3 }{2};r_{+}^{2},r_{-}^{2}\right).
References for other inductance problems solvable in terms of elliptic integrals are given in ( , pp. 8 and 283) .

Generalizations of elliptic integrals appear in analysis of modular theorems ofRamanujan ( ( ) ); analysis of Selberg integrals ( ( ) ); use of Legendre’s relation (LABEL:eq:EL.LT.LR) to compute \pi to high precision ( ( , p. 26) ).
Elliptic integrals appear in lattice models of critical phenomena ( ( ) ); theories of layered materials ( ( ) ); fluid dynamics ( ( ) ); string theory ( ( ) ); astrophysics ( ( ) ).

Numerical differences between the variables of a symmetric integral can be reduced in magnitude by successive factors of 4 by repeated applications of the duplication theorem, as shown by (LABEL:eq:EL.AD.DF).

When the differences are moderately small, the iteration is stopped, the elementary symmetric functions of certain differences are calculated, and a polynomial consisting of a fixed number of terms of the sum in (LABEL:eq:EL.SE.E1) is evaluated. For R_{F} the polynomial of degree 7, for example, is 1-\tfrac{1}{10}E_{2}+\tfrac{1}{14}E_{3}+\tfrac{1}{24}E_{2}^{2}-\tfrac{3}{44}E_ {2}E_{3}-\tfrac{5}{208}E_{2}^{3}+\tfrac{3}{104}E_{3}^{2}+\tfrac{1}{16}E_{2}^{2 }E_{3}, where the elementary symmetric functions E_{s} are defined by (LABEL:eq:EL.SE.E).
If (LABEL:eq:EL.CO.DU1) is used instead of its first five terms, then the factor (3r)^{-1/6} in ( , (2.2)) is changed to (3r)^{-1/8}.

For both R_{D} and R_{J} the factor (r/4)^{-1/6} in ( , (2.18)) is changed to (r/5)^{-1/8} when the following polynomial of degree 7 (the same for both) is used instead of its first seven terms: 1-\tfrac{3}{14}E_{2}+\tfrac{1}{6}E_{3}+\tfrac{9}{88}E_{2}^{2}-\tfrac{3}{22}E_{ 4}-\tfrac{9}{52}E_{2}E_{3}+\tfrac{3}{26}E_{5}-\tfrac{1}{16}E_{2}^{3}+\tfrac{3} {40}E_{3}^{2}+\tfrac{3}{20}E_{2}E_{4}+\tfrac{45}{272}E_{2}^{2}E_{3}-\tfrac{9}{ 68}(E_{3}E_{4}+E_{2}E_{5}).
Polynomials of still higher degree can be obtained from (LABEL:eq:EL.SE.TE) and (LABEL:eq:EL.SE.E1).
The duplication method starts with computation of \lambda_{0}=\sqrt{x}\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{y}\sqrt{z}+\sqrt{z}\sqrt{x}.
The reductions in §LABEL:sec:EL.CI.RT represent x,y,z as squares, for example x=U_{12}^{2} in (LABEL:eq:EL.CI.F).
Because U_{12} may be real and negative, or even complex, care is needed to ensure \sqrt{x}=U_{12} , and similarly for y and z.
This precaution is needed only for \lambda_{0}.
Alternatively, the first duplication is done analytically as in ( ) , where further information can be found.

Three applications of (LABEL:eq:EL.AD.DF) yield R_{F}\left(1,2,4\right)=R_{F}\left(z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\right), where, in the notation of (LABEL:eq:EL.SE.E1) with a=-\frac{1}{2} and n=3 , \begin{aligned} \displaystyle z_{1}&\displaystyle=2.10985\;99098\;8,\\ \displaystyle z_{3}&\displaystyle=2.15673\;49098\;8,\\ \displaystyle Z_{1}&\displaystyle=0.00977\;77253\;5,\end{aligned}\quad\begin{ aligned} \displaystyle z_{2}&\displaystyle=2.12548\;49098\;8,\\ \displaystyle A&\displaystyle=2.13069\;32432\;1,\\ \displaystyle Z_{2}&\displaystyle=0.00244\;44313\;4,\end{aligned}\\ {Z_{3}=-Z_{1}-Z_{2}=-0.01222\;21566\;9,}\\ {E_{2}=\Sci{-1.25480\;14}{-4},\quad E_{3}=\Sci{-2.9212}{-7}.
} The first five terms of (LABEL:eq:EL.CO.DU1) suffice for R_{F}\left(1,2,4\right)=0.68508\;58166\dots.
All cases of R_{F} , R_{C} , R_{J} , and R_{D} are computed by essentially the same procedure (after transforming Cauchy principal values by means of (LABEL:eq:EL.VP.JPV) and (LABEL:eq:EL.LD.CPC)).
Complex values of the variables are allowed, with some restrictions in the case of R_{J} that are sufficient but not always necessary.
The computation is slowest for complete cases.
For details see ( ) and ( ) .
In the Appendix of the last reference it is shown how to compute R_{J} without computing R_{C} more than once.
Because of cancellations in (LABEL:eq:EL.AD.DG) it is advisable to compute R_{G} from R_{F} and R_{D} by (LABEL:eq:EL.CF.GFD) or else to use §LABEL:sec:EL.CO.QU.
Legendre’s integrals can be computed from symmetric integrals by using the relations in §LABEL:sec:EL.OF.LE. Note the remark following (LABEL:eq:EL.OF.LE5).
If (LABEL:eq:EL.OF.LE3) is used when 0\leq k^{2}\leq 1 , cancellations may lead to loss of significant figures when k^{2} is close to 1 and \phi>\pi/4 , as shown by ( ) .
The cancellations can be eliminated, however, by using (LABEL:eq:EL.OF.LE4).
Accurate values of F\left(\phi,k\right)-E\left(\phi,k\right) for k^{2} near 0 can be obtained from R_{D} by (LABEL:eq:EL.LD.D) and(LABEL:eq:EL.OF.LE6).

Complete cases of Legendre’s integrals and symmetric integrals can be computed with quadratic convergence by the AGM method (including Bartky transformations), using the equations in §LABEL:sec:EL.LQ.GM and §LABEL:sec:EL.QT.GM, respectively.

The incomplete integrals R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right) and R_{G}\left(x,y,z\right) can be computed by successive transformations in which two of the three variables converge quadratically to a common value and the integrals reduce to R_{C} , accompanied by two quadratically convergent series in the case of R_{G} ; compare ( , §§5,6) .

(In Legendre’s notation the modulus k approaches 0 or 1.) Let 2a_{n+1}=a_{n}+\sqrt{a_{n}^{2}-c_{n}^{2}}, 2c_{n+1}=a_{n}-\sqrt{a_{n}^{2}-c_{n}^{2}}=c_{n}^{2}/(2a_{n+1}), 2t_{n+1}=t_{n}+\sqrt{t_{n}^{2}+\theta c_{n}^{2}}, where n=0,1,2,\dots , and 0<c_{0}<a_{0}, t_{0}\geq 0, t_{0}^{2}+\theta a_{0}^{2}\geq 0, \theta=\pm 1.
Then (LABEL:eq:EL.QT.IF) implies that R_{F}\left(t_{n}^{2},t_{n}^{2}+\theta c_{n}^{2},t_{n}^{2}+\theta a_{n}^{2}\right) is independent of n.

As n\to\infty , c_{n} , a_{n} , and t_{n} converge quadratically to limits 0 , M , and T , respectively; hence R_{F}\left(t_{0}^{2},t_{0}^{2}+\theta c_{0}^{2},t_{0}^{2}+\theta a_{0}^{2} \right)=R_{F}\left(T^{2},T^{2},T^{2}+\theta M^{2}\right)=R_{C}\left(T^{2}+ \theta M^{2},T^{2}\right).
If t_{0}=a_{0} and \theta=-1 , so that t_{n}=a_{n} , then this procedure reduces to the AGM method for the complete integral.

The step from n to n+1 is an ascending Landen transformation if \theta=1 (leading ultimately to a hyperbolic case of R_{C} ) or a descending Gauss transformation if \theta=-1 (leading to a circular case of R_{C} ).

If x , y , and z are permuted so that 0\leq x<y<z , then the computation of R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right) is fastest if we make c_{0}^{2}\leq a_{0}^{2}/2 by choosing \theta=1 when y<(x+z)/2 or \theta=-1 when y\geq(x+z)/2.
We compute R_{F}\left(1,2,4\right) by setting \theta=1 , t_{0}=c_{0}=1 , and a_{0}=\sqrt{3}.
Hence R_{F}\left(1,2,4\right)=R_{C}\left(T^{2}+M^{2},T^{2}\right)=0.68508\;58166 , in agreement with (LABEL:eq:EL.CO.DUb).
Here R_{C} is computed either by the duplication algorithm in ( ) or via (LABEL:eq:EL.LD.CH).

To (LABEL:eq:EL.CO.QT2) add h_{n}=\sqrt{t_{n}^{2}+\theta a_{n}^{2}}, h_{n}=h_{n-1}\frac{t_{n}}{\sqrt{t_{n}^{2}+\theta c_{n}^{2}}}, Then 2\!R_{G}\left(t_{0}^{2},t_{0}^{2}+\theta c_{0}^{2},t_{0}^{2}+\theta a_{0}^{2} \right)=\left(t_{0}^{2}+\theta\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}2^{m-1}c_{m}^{2}\right)R_{C} \left(T^{2}+\theta M^{2},T^{2}\right)+h_{0}+\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}2^{m}(h_{m}-h_{ m-1}).

If the iteration of (LABEL:eq:EL.CO.QT2) and (LABEL:eq:EL.CO.QTh) is stopped when c_{s}<\sqrt{r}t_{s} ( M and T being approximated by a_{s} and t_{s} , and the infinite series being truncated), then the relative error in R_{F} and R_{G} is less than r if we neglect terms of order r^{2}.
F\left(\phi,k\right) can be evaluated by using (LABEL:eq:EL.OF.LE2).
E\left(\phi,k\right) can be evaluated by using (LABEL:eq:EL.OF.LEG), and R_{D} by using (LABEL:eq:EL.CF.GFD), but cancellations may become significant.
( , pp. 499, 504) uses descending Landen transformations for both F\left(\phi,k\right) and E\left(\phi,k\right).
A summary for F\left(\phi,k\right) is given in ( , §3) .
For computation of K\left(k\right) and E\left(k\right) with complex k see ( ) and ( ) .
(LABEL:eq:EL.QT.IJ) reduces to 0=0 if p=x or p=y , and (LABEL:eq:EL.QT.ID) reduces to 0=0 if z=x or z=y.
Near these points there will be loss of significant figures in the computation of R_{J} or R_{D}.
Descending Gauss transformations of \Pi\left(\phi,\alpha^{2},k\right) (see (LABEL:eq:EL.LQ.GAP)) are used in ( ) to compute a large table (see §LABEL:sec:EL.TA.LI).
This method loses significant figures in \rho if \alpha^{2} and k^{2} are nearly equal unless they are given exact values—as they can be for tables.
If \alpha^{2}=k^{2} , then the method fails, but the function can be expressed by (LABEL:eq:EL.LP.Pi2) in terms of E\left(\phi,k\right) , for which ( ) uses ascending Landen transformations.
Computation of Legendre’s integrals of all three kinds by quadratic transformation is described by ( , pp. 128–159, 208–230) .
Quadratic transformations can be applied to compute Bulirsch’s integrals (§LABEL:sec:EL.LD.BI).
The function \mathrm{cel}\left(k_{c},p,a,b\right) is computed by successive Bartky transformations ( ( ) , ( ) ).

The function \mathrm{el2}\left(x,k_{c},a,b\right) is computed by descending Landen transformations if x is real, or by descending Gauss transformations if x is complex ( ( ) ). Remedies for cancellation when x is real and near 0 are supplied in ( ) .
See also ( ) and ( ) .

( ) extend Bartky’s transformation to \mathrm{el3}\left(x,k_{c},p\right) by expressing it in terms of the first incomplete integral, a complete integral of the third kind, and a more complicated integral to which Bartky’s method can be applied. The cases k_{c}^{2}/2\leq p<\infty and -\infty<p<k_{c}^{2}/2 require different treatment for numerical purposes, and again precautions are needed to avoid cancellations.
( ) compares the use of theta functions for computation of K\left(k\right) , E\left(k\right) , and K\left(k\right)-E\left(k\right) , 0\leq k^{2}\leq 1 , with four other methods.
Also, see ( ) for a special case of K\left(k\right).
For computation of Legendre’s integral of the third kind, see ( , §§17.7 and 17.8, Examples 15, 17, 19, and 20) .
For integrals of the second and third kinds see ( , §§3.4–3.7) .
Numerical quadrature is slower than most methods for the standard integrals but can be useful for elliptic integrals that have complicated representations in terms of standard integrals.
See §LABEL:sec:NM.QUA.

For series expansions of Legendre’s integrals see §LABEL:sec:EL.LS. Faster convergence of power series for K\left(k\right) and E\left(k\right) can be achieved by using (LABEL:eq:EL.LS.K1) and (LABEL:eq:EL.LS.E1) in the right-hand sides of (LABEL:eq:EL.LQ.LA2).
A three-part computational procedurefor \Pi\left(\phi,\alpha^{2},k\right) is described by ( ) for \alpha^{2}<1.

When the values of complete integrals are known, addition theorems with \psi=\pi/2 (§LABEL:sec:EL.LA.SF) ease the computation of functions such as F\left(\phi,k\right) when \frac{1}{2}\pi-\phi is small and positive.
Similarly, §LABEL:sec:EL.AD.SF eases the computation of functions such as R_{F}\left(x,y,z\right) when x ( >0 ) is small compared with \min(y,z).
These special theorems are also useful for checking computer codes.
For fast methods for computing the incomplete elliptic integral of the first kind see ( ) and ( ) .

For check values of symmetric integrals with real or complex variables to 14S see ( ) .

Minimax polynomial approximations (§LABEL:sec:NM.APT.MPA) for K\left(k\right) and E\left(k\right) in terms of m=k^{2} with 0\leq m<1 can be found in ( , §17.3) with maximum absolute errors ranging from 4×10⁻⁵ to 2×10⁻⁸.
Approximations of thesame type for K\left(k\right) and E\left(k\right) for 0<k\leq 1 are given in ( ) with maximum absolute errors ranging from 4×10⁻⁵ to 4×10⁻¹⁸.
( ) gives Chebyshev-series expansions (§LABEL:sec:NM.APT.CHEB) with maximum precision 25D.
Approximations for Legendre’s complete or incomplete integrals of all three kinds, derived by Padé approximation of the square root in the integrand, are given in ( ) .
They are valid over parts of the complex k and \phi planes.

The accuracy is controlled by the number of terms retained in the approximation; for real variables the number of significant figures appears to be roughly twice the number of terms retained, perhaps even for \phi near \pi/2 with the improvements made in the 1970 reference.
